title: Your E-Portfolio
text: Hi, I’m Aidan. Born and raised in Toronto, Ontario, I completed my Bachelor of Science in Biodiversity and Conservation Biology at the University of Toronto in 2023 with minors in GIS and philosophy. I then moved to Vancouver, BC, to expand my knowledge and skills in geomatics and remote sensing in the Master of Geomatics for Environmental Management program at the University of British Columbia. My focus during this graduate degree has been applications of remotely sensed data for animal conservation on campus.

As your career progresses, this list may become quite long, so be sure to organize things. You may want to point to ‘most recent’ publications, or categorize things by project/topic.

title: Content & Deliverables
text:
Project Deliverable 1
This is a sample page where you can archive project deliverables.

title: Content and deliverables
text:
Capstone project for the MGEM program. This project involved classifying land cover at the University of British Columbia Vancouver campus and then modelling animal and human movement across the landscape to identify points of potential conflict and potential corridors to promote coexistence.


Sample leaflet - for detailed leaflet instructions, visit the FCOR 599 workshop archive page here.









Python Arcpy cursor used to generate building capacity numbers based on building code limits to estimate human presence numbers within each building on campus.
##checks if there is already a field for building capacity created
if "capacity" not in [f.name for f in arcpy.ListFields("buildings_clipped")]:
  
    ##creates new field in attribute table
    arcpy.management.AddField(in_table="buildings_clipped",
                              field_name="capacity", 
                              field_type="FLOAT")

##creating update cursor for buildings_clipped feature, looking at four specific fields
with arcpy.da.UpdateCursor("buildings_clipped", field_names=["Shape_Area", "bldg_usage", "max_floors", "capacity"]) as cursor:
  
    ##for every row, if the row has a building area value, then the building max capacity is added to the new field
    for row in cursor:
      
        if row[0] is not None:
            ##max capacity is building area * number of floors * 0.4 people per m^2
            row[3] = row[0] * row[2] * 0.4 
        else:
            pass

        cursor.updateRow(row)

title: Content & Deliverables
text:
You can also provide a frame linking to external websites. For example, here is a link to a Google Earth Engine application I developed. The full-screen GEE application is available here in case you’re interested.
(To use the GEE tool, navigate to any city you’d like, hit apply filters, and click anywhere on the map to retrieve a time-series of Landsat surface temperature observations for that point. Areas where the maximum temp exceeded 35 degrees Celsius in your date-range are highlighted in red.)

title: Content & Deliverables
section: Urban ecology: Stream temperature as a function of impermeable land cover
text:
Urban ecology: Stream temperature as a function of impermeable land cover
Increased impermeable surface cover increases runoff and temperatures in urban streams with ecological implications. Analysis of impermeable surface area at sites in Toronto region watersheds was carried out to test the relevance of this relationship. Surface impermeability is correlated with mean stream temperature at large scales, but minimum and maximum temperatures display no relationship. This may be due to the homogeneous urban landscape, the impact of cool water entering upstream at headwaters, or other physical characteristics of urban streams.

title: Content and deliverables
text:
Abstract:
Increased impermeable surface cover increases runoff and temperatures in urban streams with ecological implications. Analysis of impermeable surface area at sites in Toronto region watersheds was carried out to test the relevance of this relationship. Surface impermeability is correlated with mean stream temperature at large scales, but minimum and maximum temperatures display no relationship. This may be due to the homogeneous urban landscape, the impact of cool water entering upstream at headwaters, or other physical characteristics of urban streams.
